title: John Chapter 12 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on John chapter 12 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: John Chapter 12 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of John Chapter 12.

questions.question: Where did Jesus go six days before the Passover?
options: Bethany
Jerusalem
Nazareth
Capernaum
questions.correctAnswer: Bethany
questions.explanation: John 12:1 states that Jesus came to Bethany six days before the Passover.

questions.question: Who served at the supper made for Jesus in Bethany?
options: Martha
Mary
Lazarus
Judas
questions.correctAnswer: Martha
questions.explanation: John 12:2 says Martha served at the supper made for Jesus.

questions.question: What did Mary anoint Jesus' feet with?
options: Ointment of spikenard
Olive oil
Myrrh
Frankincense
questions.correctAnswer: Ointment of spikenard
questions.explanation: John 12:3 mentions Mary took a pound of ointment of spikenard to anoint Jesus' feet.

questions.question: Who questioned why the ointment was not sold and given to the poor?
options: Judas Iscariot
Peter
John
Thomas
questions.correctAnswer: Judas Iscariot
questions.explanation: John 12:4-5 records Judas Iscariot asking why the ointment was not sold for three hundred pence and given to the poor.

questions.question: Why did Judas Iscariot really object to the ointment being used?
options: He was a thief
He cared for the poor
He disliked Mary
He wanted to keep the ointment
questions.correctAnswer: He was a thief
questions.explanation: John 12:6 explains Judas did not care for the poor but was a thief and carried the money bag.

questions.question: What did Jesus say about the ointment Mary used?
options: She kept it for the day of my burying
It was wasted
It should be sold
It was too costly
questions.correctAnswer: She kept it for the day of my burying
questions.explanation: John 12:7 records Jesus saying Mary kept the ointment for the day of His burial.

questions.question: What did Jesus say about the poor in John 12:8?
options: The poor always ye have with you
Give all to the poor
Do not help the poor
The poor will be blessed
questions.correctAnswer: The poor always ye have with you
questions.explanation: John 12:8 states that the poor are always present, but Jesus will not be with them always.

questions.question: Why did many Jews come to see Jesus at Bethany?
options: To see Lazarus, whom Jesus raised from the dead
To hear Jesus preach
To worship at the temple
To buy ointment
questions.correctAnswer: To see Lazarus, whom Jesus raised from the dead
questions.explanation: John 12:9 says many came not only for Jesus but also to see Lazarus whom He raised.

questions.question: What did the chief priests plan to do because of Lazarus?
options: Put Lazarus to death
Make Lazarus a priest
Exile Lazarus
Ignore Lazarus
questions.correctAnswer: Put Lazarus to death
questions.explanation: John 12:10 records the chief priests' consultation to put Lazarus to death.

questions.question: What did the crowds do when Jesus came to Jerusalem on the next day?
options: Took palm branches and cried Hosanna
Threw stones
Sang hymns quietly
Left the city
questions.correctAnswer: Took palm branches and cried Hosanna
questions.explanation: John 12:12-13 describes the crowd taking palm branches and shouting Hosanna as Jesus entered Jerusalem.

questions.question: On what animal did Jesus ride into Jerusalem?
options: A young ass
A horse
A camel
A chariot
questions.correctAnswer: A young ass
questions.explanation: John 12:14 says Jesus found a young ass and sat on it as He entered Jerusalem.

questions.question: True or False: The disciples immediately understood the significance of Jesus riding on a young ass.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 12:16 states the disciples did not understand at first but remembered after Jesus was glorified.

questions.question: True or False: Greeks came to Philip asking to see Jesus.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: John 12:20-21 records certain Greeks requesting Philip to show them Jesus.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'Except a corn of wheat fall into the ground and ______, it abideth alone:'
options: die
grow
sleep
hide
questions.correctAnswer: die
questions.explanation: John 12:24 says except a corn of wheat falls into the ground and dies, it abides alone.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus said He came to judge the world.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 12:47 says Jesus did not come to judge the world but to save it.

medium.title: John Chapter 12 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from John Chapter 12 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does John 12 teach us about generosity and honoring Jesus in our personal devotion?
options: By anointing Jesus' feet with costly ointment and wiping them with hair
By selling all possessions to give to the poor
By fasting and praying for days
By publicly preaching in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: By anointing Jesus' feet with costly ointment and wiping them with hair
questions.explanation: Mary’s act of anointing Jesus' feet with expensive ointment and wiping it with her hair shows deep personal devotion and generosity (John 12:3, 7-8). Jesus values heartfelt worship and preparing for His burial more than mere financial giving.

questions.question: What warning does Jesus give about loving one's life in this world, based on John 12?
options: He that loveth his life shall lose it; he that hateth his life shall keep it unto life eternal
He that loves his life shall be blessed with wealth
He that hates his life will be punished
He that seeks pleasure will find peace
questions.correctAnswer: He that loveth his life shall lose it; he that hateth his life shall keep it unto life eternal
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches that attachment to worldly life leads to loss, but self-denial and focus on eternal life bring true preservation (John 12:25). This calls for humility and contentment with God's plan.

questions.question: How does John 12 emphasize the importance of serving Jesus in daily life?
options: If any man serve me, let him follow me; and where I am, there shall also my servant be
Serve only when convenient
Serve only in large crowds
Serve only after gaining wealth
questions.correctAnswer: If any man serve me, let him follow me; and where I am, there shall also my servant be
questions.explanation: Jesus highlights that true service involves following Him closely, sharing in His presence and receiving honor from the Father (John 12:26). This teaches obedience and faithfulness in Christian service.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear about trials. Based on John 12, what biblical truth can you share about Jesus’ attitude toward difficult moments?
options: Jesus was troubled in soul but accepted the hour as His purpose
Jesus avoided difficult situations
Jesus always remained joyful without concern
Jesus refused to face suffering
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus was troubled in soul but accepted the hour as His purpose
questions.explanation: Jesus expressed deep trouble about His approaching suffering yet embraced it as the reason for His coming (John 12:27-28). This teaches perseverance and trust in God’s plan during trials.

questions.question: What does Jesus mean by saying, 'Except a corn of wheat fall into the ground and die, it abideth alone: but if it die, it bringeth forth much fruit'?
options: Self-sacrifice leads to fruitful spiritual life
Planting crops is necessary for survival
Avoiding suffering ensures success
Wealth guarantees blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Self-sacrifice leads to fruitful spiritual life
questions.explanation: Jesus uses the metaphor of a seed dying to produce fruit to teach that losing self for His sake results in abundant spiritual growth and impact (John 12:24). This encourages humility and perseverance.

questions.question: How do the people’s actions in John 12 when Jesus entered Jerusalem demonstrate faith and worship?
options: They took palm branches and shouted, 'Hosanna! Blessed is the King of Israel!'
They ignored Jesus completely
They challenged Jesus publicly
They scattered and fled
questions.correctAnswer: They took palm branches and shouted, 'Hosanna! Blessed is the King of Israel!'
questions.explanation: The crowd’s worshipful reception with palm branches and praise shows recognizing Jesus as King and Messiah (John 12:12-13). This models open faith and communal praise.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus came to judge the world immediately according to John 12.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jesus clearly states He did not come to judge the world but to save it (John 12:47). Judgment comes later for those who reject Him (John 12:48).

questions.question: True or False: The Pharisees were pleased that many people followed Jesus after He raised Lazarus from the dead.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The Pharisees were displeased and sought to kill Lazarus because many believed in Jesus through him (John 12:10-11). This reflects opposition to genuine faith.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jesus said, 'I am come a ______ into the world, that whosoever believeth on me should not abide in darkness.'
options: light
king
shepherd
teacher
questions.correctAnswer: light
questions.explanation: Jesus identifies Himself as the light that brings people out of spiritual darkness when they believe (John 12:46). This teaches reliance on Him for guidance and truth.

questions.question: How does John 12 illustrate the importance of faith in Jesus as sent by the Father?
options: Believing in Jesus is believing in God who sent Him
Believing in Jesus only is enough without God
Faith is unnecessary for salvation
Only miracles prove faith
questions.correctAnswer: Believing in Jesus is believing in God who sent Him
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches that to believe in Him is to believe in the Father who sent Him (John 12:44-45). This underscores the unity of God’s revelation and the call to trust both.

questions.question: What does the crowd’s misunderstanding about 'The Son of man must be lifted up' teach us about spiritual insight and growth?
options: Spiritual understanding often comes after Jesus is glorified
Everyone understands Jesus’ words immediately
The crowd fully comprehended Jesus’ death
Jesus refused to explain His mission
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual understanding often comes after Jesus is glorified
questions.explanation: The disciples did not understand at first but recalled the scriptures after Jesus’ glorification (John 12:16, 33). This shows patience in spiritual growth and the unfolding of God’s plan.

questions.question: How does John 12 demonstrate the value of honest confession and courage in faith despite opposition?
options: Many believed but did not confess Jesus for fear of being put out of the synagogue
Everyone openly confessed Jesus without fear
No one believed in Jesus
Confession was not necessary
questions.correctAnswer: Many believed but did not confess Jesus for fear of being put out of the synagogue
questions.explanation: Though some rulers believed, they feared losing social standing and did not openly confess Jesus (John 12:42-43). This warns believers to prioritize God’s praise over man’s.

questions.question: According to John 12, what is the consequence of rejecting Jesus' words?
options: The word spoken by Jesus will judge them on the last day
They will be ignored forever
They will receive immediate punishment
They will be praised by men
questions.correctAnswer: The word spoken by Jesus will judge them on the last day
questions.explanation: Jesus states that rejecting His words leads to judgment by the very words He spoke (John 12:48), emphasizing the seriousness of obedience and faith.

questions.question: How does the interaction with the Greeks in John 12 encourage believers about sharing their faith with others from different backgrounds?
options: Believers should be open to seekers from all nations and share Jesus with them
Faith should be kept within one's own group only
Outsiders are not interested in faith
Witnessing is only for religious leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should be open to seekers from all nations and share Jesus with them
questions.explanation: Greeks seeking Jesus show that faith crosses cultural boundaries (John 12:20-21). Philip and Andrew bring this request to Jesus, demonstrating openness and evangelism.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and recognition of God’s timing can be drawn from Jesus riding a young donkey into Jerusalem?
options: True kingship is humble and fulfills prophecy
Power is shown by riding horses and chariots
Jesus refused to fulfill Old Testament prophecies
Humility means avoiding public recognition
questions.correctAnswer: True kingship is humble and fulfills prophecy
questions.explanation: Jesus riding a young ass fulfills prophecy (John 12:14-15) and models humble leadership, teaching believers to value humility and God’s ordained timing.

hard.title: John Chapter 12 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from John Chapter 12.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus riding on a young ass as described in John 12:14-15?
options: It fulfills the prophecy of Zechariah about the coming King
It symbolizes Jesus' humility and peace
It represents the Davidic kingship
All of the above
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above
questions.explanation: John 12:14-15 explicitly cites the prophecy about the King coming on an ass's colt, fulfilling Zechariah 9:9. This act is a typology of humility contrasting a conquering king on a horse, signaling peace and Davidic lineage.

questions.question: In John 12:3, Mary anoints Jesus' feet with a costly ointment. What is the Greek word for 'ointment' used here, and what does it culturally signify?
options: Spikenard; a rare and expensive perfume used for burial and honor
Myrrh; a common spice for cooking
Frankincense; a gift for temple worship
Olive oil; used for anointing kings
questions.correctAnswer: Spikenard; a rare and expensive perfume used for burial and honor
questions.explanation: The text uses 'spikenard,' a costly and aromatic ointment from the Himalayas, symbolizing honor and foreshadowing Jesus' burial (John 12:3,7).

questions.question: How does Jesus’ statement in John 12:24 about the corn of wheat falling into the ground illustrate a theme of death and resurrection in Scripture?
options: It uses agricultural imagery to symbolize death bringing new life
It references Old Testament sacrificial systems
It is an allusion to the creation narrative
It contrasts pagan fertility rites
questions.correctAnswer: It uses agricultural imagery to symbolize death bringing new life
questions.explanation: Jesus uses the metaphor of a seed dying to produce much fruit, illustrating the necessity of his death for salvation and the theme of resurrection prevalent throughout Scripture (John 12:24).

questions.question: What does the voice from heaven in John 12:28-29 signify in the context of Jewish expectations and divine revelation?
options: God’s confirmation of Jesus’ mission and glorification
A thunderstorm interpreted as divine judgment
An angelic message to the crowd
A sign of the coming Messiah's defeat
questions.correctAnswer: God’s confirmation of Jesus’ mission and glorification
questions.explanation: The voice declares God's glorification of His name, affirming Jesus’ divine mission, though some witnesses misunderstood it as thunder or angelic speech (John 12:28-29).

questions.question: Why do the Pharisees say in John 12:19, 'Behold, the world is gone after him,' and how does this reflect their concerns?
options: They recognize Jesus’ growing influence threatening their authority
They see Jesus as a political revolutionary
They fear losing control over the temple
They want to join Jesus’ movement
questions.correctAnswer: They recognize Jesus’ growing influence threatening their authority
questions.explanation: The Pharisees express alarm that Jesus’ miracles and teachings attract large crowds, undermining their religious leadership (John 12:19).

questions.question: In John 12:20-22, Greeks seek Jesus through Philip and Andrew. What does their request symbolize about the expanding scope of Jesus' ministry?
options: The inclusion of Gentiles in salvation
The political alliance with Greeks
A test of Jesus’ teachings
A cultural exchange during Passover
questions.correctAnswer: The inclusion of Gentiles in salvation
questions.explanation: The Greeks’ desire to see Jesus signifies the opening of Jesus’ message beyond Israel, foreshadowing the Gentile mission (John 12:20-22).

questions.question: What does Jesus mean in John 12:25 when he says, 'He that loveth his life shall lose it; and he that hateth his life in this world shall keep it unto life eternal'?
options: Self-sacrifice leads to eternal life
Worldly attachments result in loss
Spiritual life transcends physical life
All of the above
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches that prioritizing worldly life leads to spiritual loss, but renouncing it in obedience leads to eternal life, a key Johannine theme (John 12:25).

questions.question: How does John 12:31-32 connect Jesus' crucifixion to cosmic judgment and redemption?
options: The crucifixion initiates judgment on evil powers
Jesus being lifted up draws all people to salvation
It reveals the defeat of the prince of this world (Satan)
All of the above
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above
questions.explanation: Jesus’ death is portrayed as both a moment of judgment on Satan and a redemptive act attracting all to salvation (John 12:31-32).

questions.question: In John 12:38-40, Isaiah’s prophecy about blindness and hardening hearts is cited. What theological concept does this illustrate?
options: Divine sovereignty in judgment
The fulfillment of Messianic prophecy
The mystery of human unbelief
All of the above
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above
questions.explanation: The quotation of Isaiah shows God’s sovereign role in judgment, the fulfillment of prophecy, and the perplexing reality of unbelief despite clear signs (John 12:38-40).

questions.question: What literary device is used in John 12:16 where the disciples only understand Jesus' actions after His glorification?
options: Foreshadowing
Irony
Typology
Allusion
questions.correctAnswer: Foreshadowing
questions.explanation: John indicates that the disciples’ later understanding after Jesus’ glorification is a literary foreshadowing of the resurrection and exaltation (John 12:16).

questions.question: How does Jesus' declaration in John 12:46, 'I am come a light into the world,' relate to Old Testament imagery?
options: It echoes the motif of God as light in Isaiah
It parallels the pillar of fire guiding Israel
It contrasts darkness as sin and ignorance
All of the above
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above
questions.explanation: Jesus identifies himself with divine light imagery found in Isaiah and Exodus, symbolizing guidance, revelation, and salvation (John 12:46).

questions.question: According to John 12:6, what was Judas Iscariot’s true motive for criticizing Mary’s anointing of Jesus?
options: He was a thief and wanted the money for himself
He cared deeply for the poor
He doubted Jesus’ identity
He wanted to honor Jesus differently
questions.correctAnswer: He was a thief and wanted the money for himself
questions.explanation: John explicitly states Judas criticized Mary’s act not out of concern for the poor but because he was a thief who stole from the common purse (John 12:6).

questions.question: True or False: In John 12:11, the chief priests sought to kill Lazarus because his resurrection caused many Jews to believe in Jesus.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: John 12:10-11 shows the chief priests plotted to kill Lazarus since his resurrection led many to believe in Jesus.

questions.question: What does Jesus mean in John 12:27 when he says, 'Now is my soul troubled; and what shall I say? Father, save me from this hour: but for this cause came I unto this hour'?
options: He expresses human distress yet submission to the divine plan
He wishes to avoid suffering but accepts it
He anticipates his glorification through suffering
All of the above
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above
questions.explanation: Jesus reveals his struggle and submission, acknowledging that his suffering is part of God’s redemptive purpose (John 12:27).

questions.question: How does John 12:44-45 emphasize the unity between Jesus and the Father?
options: Believing in Jesus is believing in the Father
Seeing Jesus is seeing the Father
Jesus reveals the Father’s nature
All of the above
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches that faith in him equates to faith in the Father and that his visible presence reveals the invisible God (John 12:44-45).

theological.title: John Chapter 12 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from John Chapter 12 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What significant event does John 12:1 describe happening six days before the Passover?
options: Jesus raising Lazarus from the dead
Jesus coming to Bethany where Lazarus was
The Last Supper
Jesus entering Jerusalem on a donkey
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus coming to Bethany where Lazarus was
questions.explanation: John 12:1 states Jesus came to Bethany where Lazarus was, whom He had raised from the dead. This highlights Jesus' power over death, fulfilling messianic prophecy (cf. John 11:43-44, Isaiah 25:8, 1 Corinthians 15:54-55).

questions.question: In John 12:3, what does Mary use to anoint Jesus' feet, and what is significant about it?
options: A pound of costly spikenard ointment
A jar of expensive perfume
Olive oil from Bethany
A bowl of water and fragrant spices
questions.correctAnswer: A pound of costly spikenard ointment
questions.explanation: Mary anointed Jesus' feet with a costly spikenard ointment, a symbol of honor and preparation for burial (John 12:3, Mark 14:3, Psalms 45:7, Proverbs 27:9). This act foreshadows Jesus' death and burial.

questions.question: According to John 12:5, what objection does Judas Iscariot raise about Mary's anointing of Jesus?
options: Why was the ointment not sold and given to the poor?
Why did she use such a costly ointment on Jesus?
Why did she anoint only Jesus’ feet?
Why was Lazarus allowed to sit at the table?
questions.correctAnswer: Why was the ointment not sold and given to the poor?
questions.explanation: Judas objects, questioning why the ointment was not sold for three hundred pence to help the poor (John 12:5). This reveals his hypocrisy as he was a thief (John 12:6), contrasting true compassion and self-interest.

questions.question: What theological truth about Jesus’ mission is revealed in John 12:23?
options: The hour has come for the Son of Man to be glorified
Jesus will establish a political kingdom
The prophetic ministry of Jesus is complete
Jesus will no longer perform miracles
questions.correctAnswer: The hour has come for the Son of Man to be glorified
questions.explanation: John 12:23 reveals the pivotal moment when Jesus declares His glorification through suffering and death, emphasizing the redemptive purpose of His mission (cf. John 17:1, Isaiah 53:10, Philippians 2:8-11, Hebrews 2:9).

questions.question: John 12:24 uses the metaphor of a grain of wheat to teach what spiritual principle?
options: Except a grain of wheat falls into the ground and dies, it remains alone but if it dies, it bears much fruit
A grain of wheat grows best in fertile soil
Harvest comes only after long waiting
The wheat must be separated from the chaff
questions.correctAnswer: Except a grain of wheat falls into the ground and dies, it remains alone but if it dies, it bears much fruit
questions.explanation: This metaphor teaches that Jesus’ death is necessary for fruitfulness and salvation (John 12:24). It reflects the doctrine of substitutionary atonement and spiritual life through death (cf. 1 Corinthians 15:36-38, Galatians 2:20, Romans 6:5).

questions.question: How does John 12:25 contrast worldly life with eternal life?
options: He who loves his life will lose it, but he who hates his life in this world will keep it to eternal life
The rich will inherit the kingdom of God
Life is to be enjoyed to the fullest
Faith in works secures eternal life
questions.correctAnswer: He who loves his life will lose it, but he who hates his life in this world will keep it to eternal life
questions.explanation: This verse teaches the paradox of discipleship: true life is found in self-denial and surrender to God (Mark 8:35, Matthew 10:39, Luke 9:24, Philippians 1:21). It contrasts temporal attachment with eternal salvation.

questions.question: What promise does Jesus give to those who serve Him according to John 12:26?
options: They will be honored by the Father and be where Jesus is
They will inherit the earth
They will never suffer
They will be rulers over nations
questions.correctAnswer: They will be honored by the Father and be where Jesus is
questions.explanation: Jesus promises that those who serve Him will follow Him and be with Him, and that the Father will honor them (John 12:26). This expresses the doctrine of eternal fellowship with Christ and divine reward (cf. Matthew 25:21, Hebrews 12:2, Revelation 3:21).

questions.question: What significant prayer does Jesus make in John 12:28, and what is the divine response?
options: Jesus prays 'Father, glorify thy name,' and a voice from heaven responds affirming glorification
Jesus prays for deliverance from suffering, and an angel appears
Jesus prays for His disciples, and the Holy Spirit descends
Jesus prays for peace, and a cloud covers Him
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus prays 'Father, glorify thy name,' and a voice from heaven responds affirming glorification
questions.explanation: Jesus petitions for God's name to be glorified, and God responds audibly confirming His glorification (John 12:28-29). This reveals the intimate relationship between Father and Son and the divine approval of Jesus' redemptive work (cf. John 17:1, Isaiah 42:8, Philippians 2:9-11).

questions.question: According to John 12:31, what cosmic event is described as taking place 'now'?
options: The judgment of this world and the casting out of the prince of the world
The destruction of Jerusalem
The resurrection of the dead
The establishment of the kingdom of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The judgment of this world and the casting out of the prince of the world
questions.explanation: John 12:31 declares that the judgment of the world and the defeat of Satan (the prince of this world) occurs through Jesus’ glorification, indicating the inauguration of eschatological victory (cf. Revelation 20:10, Colossians 2:15, Hebrews 2:14, 1 John 3:8).

questions.question: What does Jesus mean by 'if I be lifted up from the earth' in John 12:32?
options: His crucifixion and exaltation will draw all men to Him
He will ascend to heaven without dying
He will be honored as a political king
He will be removed from the earth permanently
questions.correctAnswer: His crucifixion and exaltation will draw all men to Him
questions.explanation: The phrase refers to Jesus' crucifixion ('lifted up') which results in drawing all people to salvation (John 3:14-15, Isaiah 52:13, Philippians 2:9-11, Hebrews 12:2). His death is the means of universal atonement and invitation.

questions.question: How do the people react in John 12:34 when Jesus speaks of the Son of Man being lifted up?
options: They express confusion, citing that Christ abides forever and question who the Son of Man is
They immediately recognize Jesus as the Messiah
They reject his teaching and call for his arrest
They plan a feast to celebrate
questions.correctAnswer: They express confusion, citing that Christ abides forever and question who the Son of Man is
questions.explanation: John 12:34 shows the crowd's misunderstanding and skepticism about Jesus’ death and messianic identity, reflecting the difficulty in grasping the suffering Messiah concept (cf. Psalm 110:1, Daniel 7:13-14, Isaiah 53, Luke 24:25-27).

questions.question: What does Jesus instruct people to do while they have 'the light' according to John 12:35-36?
options: Walk in the light and believe in it to become children of light
Celebrate with joy and share the light
Build a temple to honor the light
Ignore the darkness and focus on the light
questions.correctAnswer: Walk in the light and believe in it to become children of light
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches the necessity of faith and obedience during the present opportunity, emphasizing spiritual vigilance and conversion (John 12:35-36; cf. Ephesians 5:8, 1 John 1:7, Psalm 27:1, Isaiah 9:2).

questions.question: According to John 12:38-40, why could many not believe in Jesus despite His miracles?
options: Because Isaiah prophesied their eyes would be blinded and hearts hardened
Because Jesus did not fulfill political expectations
Because they were deceived by the Pharisees
Because they demanded more miracles
questions.correctAnswer: Because Isaiah prophesied their eyes would be blinded and hearts hardened
questions.explanation: John cites Isaiah’s prophecy explaining spiritual blindness and hardness of heart that prevents belief (Isaiah 6:9-10, Romans 11:8, 2 Corinthians 4:4, Hebrews 3:8). This reveals human resistance to divine revelation due to sin.

questions.question: What does John 12:44-45 teach about the relationship between belief in Jesus and belief in the Father?
options: Believing in Jesus is believing in the Father who sent Him
Belief in Jesus is separate from belief in the Father
Only the Father is to be worshiped, not Jesus
Jesus is to be believed only after the Father is believed
questions.correctAnswer: Believing in Jesus is believing in the Father who sent Him
questions.explanation: Jesus clarifies the unity of the Father and Son in revelation and salvation (John 12:44-45). This supports orthodox Christology that faith in Christ is faith in God (John 10:30, John 14:9, Colossians 1:15-20, Hebrews 1:3).

questions.question: What is the purpose of Jesus coming as 'a light into the world' as stated in John 12:46?
options: That whoever believes in Him should not remain in darkness
To perform miracles and heal the sick
To establish a new law replacing the old
To judge the nations immediately
questions.correctAnswer: That whoever believes in Him should not remain in darkness
questions.explanation: Jesus came to bring spiritual illumination and salvation, overcoming sin and ignorance (John 12:46, Isaiah 9:2, John 8:12, Ephesians 5:8, 1 John 1:5). Belief in Him results in deliverance from spiritual darkness.
